creep.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to move in a quiet, careful way, especially to avoid attracting attention
creep.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Johann would creep into the gallery to listen to the singers.
He crept back up the stairs, trying to avoid the ones that creaked.
creep.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: if something such as an insect, small animal, or car creeps, it moves slowly and quietly
creep.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: a caterpillar creeping down my arm
creep.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: to gradually enter something and change it
creep.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: Funny how religion is creeping into the environmental debate.
creep.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: if a plant creeps, it grows or climbs up or along a particular place
creep.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: ivy creeping up the walls of the building
creep.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: if mist, clouds etc creep, they gradually fill or cover a place
creep.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: Fog was creeping into the valley.
creep.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: to be insincerely nice to someone, especially someone in authority, in order to gain an advantage for yourself
creep.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: I’m not the kind of person to creep to anybody.
creep.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: someone who tries to make you like them or do things for them by being insincerely nice to you
creep.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: Don’t try and flatter her – she doesn’t approve of creeps.
